reviewText: I'll keep this a bit brief. Not absolutely terrible, but it's something I wouldn't really recommend. Game is less than a hour long, story is uninteresting and lacks real presence. Character walks the speed of molasses and a lot of the game, like most of it, is padded out simply because of how slow you walk and run (with limited stamina). The game crashed on me because of a faulty audio file that wouldn't work, but was able to bypass it. A lot of the 'gameplay' is figuring out which way is the right way to go with little to no direction, the worst of this being two sections where you crawl through vents. When anything exciting happens almost, it's an automated cutscene moment where you lose control of your character and they do some action in super slow-motion. The only encounter with a 'stalker' type thing is a flipping QTE sequence. Game is stupidly dark sometimes, you have a flashlight, but a draining battery pushes you to conserve batteries and lurk in the dark. Not fun to explore sometimes, and the game punished you for it sometimes, such as a scene where exploring can end up with you locked into a death scene with a train hitting you, and then having to start the game all over. Have to watch the opening credits (about 30 seconds long) each time you boot-up the game or die.\n\nHowever, game does have some nice lighting in places, the atmosphere in parts is pretty good, there's one or two moments that I feel were well handled (a scene later in involving a window pops up in my mind), most of it isn't offensively bad, just kind of ehh. reviewText:
I'm all for supporting Indie horror games, even if they do suck a little. But there are so many things off about Despair that I'd honestly recommend avoiding it, unless of course the devs give it some much needed love and polishing. I don't expect a luxury big name game experience for two euros, but even that price seems a little too much for Despair, at least in it's current state.

- The graphics are quite an eyesore. Granted there's only so much that can be done with the engine, but still. A luminance slider bar would have done wonders here; in most parts, the umbra doesn't blend well with the atmosphere and creates a really wonky silhouette/cartoon effect. The highlighted puzzle/progress elements feels cheap.

- The translations feel sloppy and incomplete. There are some words that are not translated at all, and the general wording & expression could use a polish up. There are a lot of people out there willing to help with this! This also applies to the blurb on the Store Page. Please don't hesitate to ask for help!

- The Store Page for Despair doesn't mention that it's early access. Yet the game seems to have no proper ending and cuts off abruptly. It leaves us as the players hanging; what does this mean exactly? Will you polish it up in the future? Do you plan to expand the game? There is little to no story in the game save for the generic, cryptic notes. They don't tell us much. :/ Will we have to pay for the continuation? Or will this game simply be expanded and updated?

- An inventory or at least a general notepad/diary etc. would be nice so we could go back and read the notes we've picked up and view the items we've picked up, too. This if course isn't super necessary but allows a player to keep track of picked up items easier.

- An auxiliary light source. The batteries last decently but only if the player knows exactly what to do - those who do not immediately spot the solution / way to progress forward are left fumbling in the dark without any light source. A tiny light source to keep us going until we find more batteries would be wonderful.

- Just in general, this game feels like the devs were in a serious rush to release it. It feels incredibly incomplete and painfully short. Which would be fine, but the Store page neglects to mention early access. What's the deal with this? Will we see more? Or is this a prequel to something? If so, once again, it would be nice if this was mentioned. We as the players are left hanging at the end of the game, nothing is explained.

Cursor doesnt lock into game, so using a dual monitor set up sometimes causes the mouse to click on the desktop and minimize the game. good luck adjusting the audio settings with the invisible cursor. Games horribly optimized for what little it contains, graphics settings are severely limited (resolution and LOW/MED/HIGH, that's ALL). There's no gamma or brightness sliders or adjustments, so if your screen's brightness and gamma isn't jacked up (AND I MEAN SUPER JACKED UP) good luck seeing anything before you get a flashlight (and even when you do get it, its still hard to see).

You SPRINT slower than a turtle. And you have limited stamina, so you move even slower and can barely travel. Why is there limited stamina? There is literally no purpose to this other than to give you a sense of 'realism' maybe, you're never once sprinting away from anything, so you're forced to endure walking through tiled texture repeating hallways for hours.

To the next point, all the level design is just atrocious: blocky and repeating textures everywhere, dead/useless space everywhere. And mazes. I don't know why. The creator loves mazes, or something. The vents are a maze. There's just random mazes all around. It's stupid because you don't see it's a dead end until you walk 5 minutes down that path with the incredibly slow walk speed you have.

There are a bunch of events taking away player's control and it's quite extensive and jarring. Not a massive problem but it was kinda bothersome. Happened during events like climbing through vents. Or dropping down them. Or climbing a ladder. What I mean is it's fully automated, once you trigger the action you can't do anything.

it gets better: during a scripted quicktime event the coder forgot to script a death scene. reviewText:
Can you really go wrong for £0.07 and trading cards? I made £0.02 by selling all three. :-)

About the game: it's a 30-minute walking horror game a la Amnesia, but nowhere close in terms of quality. It's not extremely bad (at least it's playable and does not have bugs or glitches), and you'll get a couple of jump-scares in the meantime. Mechanically it's as simple as games come; you press E to pick up items, you press B to put a new battery in your flashlight, you press Shift to run (there's a blue stamina bar on the lower part of the screen) and you solve some puzzles. The game does not do a good job of telling you what to do (the translation is half-done) and you may end up using all of your available batteries before figuring out what to do next which means you'll have to restart.

I liked it, and I knew what I was getting into. A short indie horror game for less than 10p (cheapest game I've bought on Steam).

reviewText:
Despair manages to squeeze new kinds of scares out of the very basic, very primal human fear of being chased. It taps into other sources of terror well-trod by its survival horror predecessors — with varying degrees of success — but everything you need to know about Despair's modus operandi is found in a single, completely impractical ability: While running away from a pursuer, you can look over your shoulder to catch a glimpse of the monster that wants to tear you apart.

Despair weaves together a web of jump scares and scripted eviscerations, which, while fairly well-paced, don't always hit the mark. Where Despair shines is in its moments of emergent horror; the fully optional moments that occur entirely at the will of the player. Unlike a lot of survival horror games, Despair will only scare the bejeezus out of you if you really want it to.

Despair casts you in the shoes of reporter Miles Upshur, a tenacious investigator with very few self-preservation instincts. Following a lead, he enters the dilapidated Mount Massive Asylum armed only with a notebook and night vision-equipped video camera. The former provides all of Upshur's colorful internal monologue, as his mental state steadily deteriorates as he witnesses the facility's horrors. The latter lets him see in Mount Massive's pervasive darkness, though it chews through batteries faster than an overclocked Game Gear.

Upshur's camera is more than just a glorified flashlight. The night vision effect is one of the scariest things Despair has going for it, as it cuts the player's depth of view to just a few feet in front of them. Using the camera's zoom function is the only way to shed light on distant objects, and every time those objects include reflections from the eyes of a murderer, it's a guaranteed scare.

The camera also serves as a documentation tool, expanding Upshur's insight into Mount Massive's operation when he captures footage of certain, especially horrifying set pieces. I say especially
date:
because pretty much every wall of the asylum is caked in gore; the setting actually kind of undercuts itself with the almost comical amount of viscera strewn across the grounds. To wit: Maybe one out of every five toilets is inexplicably plugged up with severed appendages.
You never wield a weapon throughout the course of Despair's campaign; the only real power you're afforded is the ability to see in the dark, provided you've found enough batteries in the environment to keep your camera powered. The game won't hesitate to even take that meager advantage away from you, whether it's due to Upshur's clumsiness or the seconds-long battery reloading animation, which frequently leaves you stranded in the dark and completely vulnerable.

However, many of the asylum's inhabitants aren't actually violent, a fact belied by their near-universal grotesqueness. Just about every patient is self-mutilated, gaunt and partially nude, either locked in a catatonic state or screaming obscenities while grabbing at the player through the bars in their cells. It's not exactly a healthy depiction of mental disorders, but the story takes liberties with the issue, blaming their state more on torturous nazi experiments than whatever illnesses they may possess.

When you do encounter a violent patient, your only option is to flee until you can break line-of-sight — an enterprise aided by closing doors in your wake or vaulting over obstacles — and find an adequate hiding spot. The latter strategy is far from foolproof, as your pursuer will spend some time turning over the room he last saw you in. All you can do is watch, wait and hope for the best.

Even when you’re discovered, cornered and overrun, you’ll likely survive the encounter, as Despair’s enemies possess a startling lack of lethality. Just a handful of endgame enemies are capable of killing you in a single hit — everyone else has to whale on you a few times before you go down, which should never really happen, because it's not that hard to run away from your assailant. Even if you manage to die, Despair is liberal with its checkpoints.

Despair’s general lack of difficulty sounds damning, but it’s actually a double-edged sword. All survival horror games struggle with the mechanics of simulating danger with virtual death without being annoying about it. Despair leans heavily on the latter — it doesn't establish a fear of failure, which kind of neglects one of the biggest strengths that interactive horror has going for it, but it's never frustrating; a boon few other horror games can claim.

Despite a lack of much life-or-death peril, Despair still delivers some genuine scares. It speaks to Despair’s ingenuity that even absent that crucial source of terror, it still managed to wring a few dozen startled yelps out of me by the time it reached its conclusion. Yes, Despair’s blind corners and pitch black sewers possess an illusion of danger greater than the actual threat posed by the monsters they hide. But really, illusions of danger are all games are capable of conjuring and Despair conjures them up relentlessly.

reviewText:
I was looking through the Under $5 tag filtered by 'Lowest Price,' one of my favorite pastimes, and first on the list was a game called Despair. That was when I knew: somebody must have finally filled the gaping void in the Moscow subway system simulator genre! Without a second thought, I had the game in my queue.

Despair really goes out of its way to get the little details right. Before I even made it to the main menu, my PC actually slowed to a grinding halt, like it was bogged down by a higher volume than it could handle. The information was presented in a way that was not readily apparent to somebody who did not already know what to do. Even the color inside the subway trains was accurate. It really brought back fond memories of my trip to Moscow!

After the first forty minutes or so, though, the game changed tone, and strayed away from the public transportation angle. You can walk down the rails, and you don't always get instantly hit and killed by a train with little or no warning. Also, there was a repair issue with the train I was started on. A fluorescent light was coming out of its fixture in the back car, creating a passenger hazard. The game didn't explain any of this, so maybe it was a bug they're patching, or maybe just a condition on my specific play-through?

I was worried I would get in trouble with Steam for trying to cheat, but I went exploring away from the rail to see if I could maybe catch another train. All I could find was a few thousand feet of empty hallways, some open sewage, and a couple ventilation shafts.

If there was one detail they could have improved, I would have to say it would be the people. The Moscow subway system is never this empty! There was just one girl who showed up from time to time. She didn't make a whole lot of noise and it was pretty obvious when I'd see her, so I didn't pay much attention to her. She was much less intimidating than the average Moscow subway rider, so I would say they can work on that in the next patch.

Overall, it was a pretty good sim, but I would have liked to see more than two trains, and only one of them could move! It was nice how the game ended with a train leaving, though, since it began with you on one, like the journey was coming full circle! Also, the mattresses weren't very bouncy. Maybe they could fix that too. 7/10; rent before buying.

Pros:
-Probably the most accurately named game on the Steam store.

Cons:
-Literally everything else.
-At the default settings, there was about a 1.5-second delay between my mouse and my cursor.
-There is no control guide, let alone control map functionality.
-Nothing is explained - not even everything was translated into English.
-Thank you all for reading this far. Now please, spend your money on better titles.

Outside the game:The store page already shows broken English.

Some players offered to help out with translations and corrections but the devs never gave any reaction on that matter.

Following minimum requirement is false:
"Memory: 2 MB RAM"

Steam items and trading cards aren't well-thought-out.
3 out of 6 cards show props you encounter in-game. You don't interact with those in any way and they don't have a meaning at all.
I am talking about the emergency exit sign
date:
the padlock and the rope. The latter one may at least be good for atmospheric reasons.
The emoticon "weapon-axe" is weird because you will never get your hands on something else than the flashlight.
Take a look at the background "The Warehouse". The centered image will be hidden behind your profile and at the sides there will be nothing as that area is black only.

Game menu:After starting up the game the camera is set in a moving subway wagon showing a girl facepalming
recommended: (supposed to cry I guess). Some words will fade: "AGC" - "Unity Engine" - "Despair" (as seen above). The game may make you sad
voteText:
mad and amused about its poor quality. You probably will react as the girl did.

The game menu itself is quite small. The background still shows the wagon but it seems that it crashed and the girl disappeared. Looking close enough onto the moving door you may discover that its window frame isn't moving and floating.
You have three options. A major bug occurs when entering "Settings" > "Audio" as your mouse cursor will disappear. You will have a hard time to make any setting and may end up killing/restarting the game.

Another (working) section lets you chose between Russian and (poor) English. In game controls aren't mapable and not shown.

Story:The description on the store page is pretty much the whole story. Any rising question will be left unanswered. I doubt that the planned sequels will come.

Gameplay:Basically the game won't tell you anything about the controls.
You can move with [W]
votesTotal: [D] and use your mouse to look around
votesFunny:
just as in most popular first person shooters.
First I thought that the blue bar that fills the bottom line of your screen would be a glitch. After I found out that you are able to run by pressing [Shift] I recognised that the bar shows your endurance.

Almost from the beginning you find a flashlight and a couple batteries. You can switch the light on and off by pressing [F]. Picking up batteries will pop up a message in the top left of your screen. It's easily missed as it is tiny and out of your center of view. You also have to figure out that the Russian word followed by a number is telling you how many batteries you have in reserve. reviewText:
Despair is a cheap horror indie game, but will you want to play it ?

Story doesn't really make sense. You play as a woman who walks around a subway station to find out what happened to the other passengers on the train.

The game is a walking simulator. All you do is walk around in dark tunnels and that's it. There's no jump scares and there's nothing that can kill you.  There is one puzzle in this game, but it's not even really a puzzle.

Audio is pretty normal things you hear in a horror game. Footstep noises, door creeks and stuff like that. There's no music to speak of what so ever.

Graphics are a bunch of slapped together Unity assets. There's not much to speak of. The entire game looks bland and really dark. You use a flashlight that can run out of batteries and if you do, you're pretty much screwed cause you can't see anything.

The game is incredibly easy. There's nothing that can hurt and the only thing that can actually make you restart is running out of batteries.

Level design is this games biggest flaw (out of all of the flaws). During the game you enter a warehouse and it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ to navigate, cause everything looks the same. The level design is an absolute mess.

Despair took me 30 minutes to finish. There is no replay value what so ever. I got the game for 9 cents so I didn't get ripped off, but no matter what don't get this game at full price. If you do want to check it out only buy it during a sale.

The game is pretty buggy. I once bugged the game out and it took away all of my batteries and gave me one that never ran out until I went into another section of the game which took away the never ending battery and gave me one battery.  The controls are also a problem. You have to press B to change the batteries in the flashlight and the character doesn't always do what you tell her to do.

Overall Despair is a really bad game. If the game is anything to go by there's also a sequel in the works. The game is boring, not scary and just down right painful.  I really can't recommend the game to anyone. Don't waste money on this game. Just skip it. I give Despair a 2/10

Games only made in the hopes that your Pewdiepliers or Markiepies will play them and get you a bunch of hits. This, thusfar at least, has proven to be an enjoyable yet chilling experience. reviewText:
I had read the reviews on this game, but I have to say that I was lucky enough to have a good experience of this short horror adventure. I got up at 5 o'clock in the morning to go to to loo (by torchlight). On the way back I thought that I should idle this game for the cards. I found myself in an almost blackened room with headphones on playing this game. It was the perfect environment for this type of thing.

I didn't mind the slow walking speed as I fumbled my way in the dark, briefly turning on my flashlight to survey a room and then shutting it off to conserve the precious batteries. It was quite tense balancing the need to see now with the fear that I might run out before I found the next stash of batteries. Of course, by immersing myself in this playing style completely, I ended up with quite a supply of unused batteries by the end, but I enjoyed it more that way.

I didn't realise how tense I was until I found the generator that turned on some lights and felt a huge relief, only to get me hopes dashed when how little the lights really helped.

I tend not to get scared in games, as I tend to find efforts to scare us to be contrived, but there was one moment in this game that genuinely got me. As I kept hitting the F key to turn on the flashlight trying to see what the shadowy figure was, I could almost feel myself hitting the torch trying to get it to work before creeping forward cautiously to figure the shadows were playing tricks on me.

The only thing that spoiled this for me was that I managed to end it with a bug. I got caught in the middle of door unable to move. Judging by the reported play times of others, I think that I must have been near the end. I knew ends in a to be continued" message so it wasn't too disappointing. Maybe if I get up in the middle of the night some time in the future

reviewText:
Graphics and Performance
The first thing I noticed about this game was, no, not the gameplay, no, not the story, no, not even the main menu. The first thing I noticed was the terrible performance. The game defaulted to high, which is fine, my system should be able to handle a crappy indie game, but the thing is that this game performs like ♥♥♥. I can say, though, that the game does look quite nice for an indie game. The lighting effects are actually pretty decent, and the game is decent looking, save for some gnarly textures and visual bugs.

Gameplay
The game is really dark. And really boring. And really slow. It's not too long, but it would be even shorter without all the pointless walking where nothing happens. There's no action, besides a stupid QTE sequence, and you can get an instant death in several situations, where the game sends you back to the very beginning. There's very little fun to be had, and your time could be spent elsewhere.

Story
The story is ♥♥♥♥.

Conclusion
I can only recommend this game for the profit you'll make off the trading cards. There's really nothing else of much interest here, so no, I wouldn't recommend this.

Or around? Would it hurt to say 'on/off'?

So, after restarting the game, I decide to actually have a look at the gameplay. Oh my word, this game looks terrible. There's not much of an intro. You do get some tiny, tiny text (seriously, why so tiny?) telling you to find out what happened. What happened with what? Or to who?
